did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Correspondence, diaries, financial records, property records and photographs of the White and Jacobson families of Coventry, Connecticut.
did.physloc: West Archives Storage Room, Family Collections Shelves

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open and available for research use. Copyright restrictions apply.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Coventry Historical Society.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], White and Jacobson Family Collection, [Box no]., Coventry Historical Society

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of George G. Jacobson II through Lyndon Wilmot, 2005. Some items were purchased by Coventry Historical Society at a sale at the home of Margaret E. Jacobson, 1999.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: James White purchased land in Coventry, CT on Ripley Hill Road in 1732 from the father of Abigail Lyman, shortly after marrying her. James White moved to Coventry, CT from Stafford Springs, CT. His descendants have owned and lived on land in the area on or near Cooper Lane for seven generations. The White family ran a cooper shop, store, farm and lumber mill. The White family was connected through marriage to the Lyman, Thompson, Colman, Yeomans, Armstrong, Washburn and Jacobson families, and through business to the Edgerton, Porter, Manning and Rose families. The White family also held local government and church responsibilities including terms as Selectman and State Representative.

The Jacobson family emigrated from Sweden. Charles Jacobson married Margaret Smith in 1877 in Glastonbury, CT. Margaret Smith emigrated from Scotland. The Jacobsons settled in Mansfield, CT where they farmed and ran a hauling and carting business. Their son George Goodwin Jacobson I married Mary Laura White, daughter of Nathan Coleman and Sarah (Yeomans) White, in 1906. The house at the corner of Cooper Lane and Root Road eventually became their home. Margaret E. Jacobson, the daughter of George Goodwin Jacobson I and Mary Laura White, lived much of her life in the house at the corner of Cooper Lane and Root Road. George Goodwin Jacobson II is the son of the brother of Margaret E. Jacobson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection documents seven generations of family members related to James White (1708-1765) and George G. Jacobson I (1883-1859) including personal correspondence, diaries, autograph books, genealogies, Bible records, photographs and poetry. Business activities of the families are recorded in business correspondence, receipts and account books. Land and property owned by the families is documented in deeds, property drawings, tax records, probate records and other legal documents. Reports, school records, student compositions, First church and library records document the history of the town of Coventry. Included are the Building Inspector's record (1964), the First Selectman and Treasurer's Reports (1867-186?) Committee, Girl Scouts, League of Women Voters and Coventry Historical Society. Records of Margaret E. Jacobson's career with the State Police are also included.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by subject and within each subject, chronologically.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p:
The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in
the library's online public access catalog.

Farming-1900-1920
Dairying-1910-1940

Coventry, (Conn.)-History
Surveying--1800-1820

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: The Kingsbury Box Factory wagon, built at the Armstrong Wagon Works on Armstrong Road in Coventry, CT and related items were also donated by the ancestors of Mary Armstrong White. Also held by Coventry Historical Society is a miniature of the house at 230 Cooper Lane, made by Walter Jacobson as a dollhouse for his daughter Donna, and an interview with George G. Jacobson II recorded by Ginney Dilk.
